title: 107_hr4634
content: The Act titled "National Capital Area Physician Emergency Assistance Act" allows for legal waivers in the National Capital Area to provide assistance during public health emergencies. During a public health emergency in the National Capital Area, physicians with valid medical licenses from an Area State government can provide health services to victims without liability for harm caused, except in cases of willful or criminal misconduct. During a public health emergency in the National Capital Area, physicians with valid medical licenses from an Area State government can provide health services without liability for harm, unless caused by willful or criminal misconduct, gross negligence, reckless misconduct, or conscious indifference to others' rights or safety. In Maryland, this provision applies to health services provided within a designated Area portion during a public health emergency declared by the Governor. During a public health emergency in Virginia or the District of Columbia, physicians with valid medical licenses can provide health services without liability for harm, similar to the National Capital Area provisions. During a public health emergency in the National Capital Area, physicians with valid medical licenses can provide health services without liability for harm, following a qualifying declaration by the Governor of Maryland, Virginia, or the Mayor of the District of Columbia. During a public health emergency, the chief executive official must notify the Secretary of Health and Human Services to officially declare the emergency. If the Secretary does not disapprove the declaration within 12 hours, the functions can be delegated to other officials. During a public health emergency, the President's declaration supersedes any declarations by state governors or the Mayor of the District of Columbia. During a public health emergency, the President's declaration supersedes any declarations by state governors or the Mayor of the District of Columbia. An emergency system in the National Capital Area is established for verifying credentials of physician volunteers. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a verification system for physician volunteers in the National Capital Area during a public health emergency. Criteria will be set for collecting and updating information on their credentials, licenses, and hospital privileges. The Secretary will establish a verification system for physician volunteers in the National Capital Area during a public health emergency. Advance registration of willing physicians will be encouraged, and grants may be provided for related activities. The Secretary is not authorized to issue requirements regarding credentials, licenses, or hospital privileges. Authorization of Appropriations: $2,000,000 for fiscal year 2003, and additional funds for fiscal years 2004 through 2007, to support the verification system for physician volunteers in the National Capital Area during public health emergencies. No requirements will be issued regarding credentials, licenses, or hospital privileges. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms related to the National Capital Area, including Area portion, Area State governments, and National Capital Area, encompassing specific jurisdictions in Maryland, Virginia, and the District of Columbia. The Act defines key terms related to the National Capital Area, including specific jurisdictions in Maryland, Virginia, and the District of Columbia. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
